summary: A letter from an unnamed individual to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's release on bail. The writer, a long-time friend and self-described trusted advisor, attests to Maxwell's character, denies any knowledge of criminal conduct, and vouches for her trustworthiness around children.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over Ghislaine Maxwell's case in the Southern District of New York, to whom this bail support letter is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the letter, facing criminal charges. The writer supports her release on bail, vouches for her character, and asserts her innocence.

connections.description: Long-time friends for over 30 years who remain in close touch; the writer considers themselves a trusted advisor to Maxwell.
Maxwell is described as an exemplary surrogate mother and friend to the writer's son, who has spent time with her and supports her.

events.title: Writer's Visit to Maxwell in US
events.description: The letter writer stayed with Ghislaine Maxwell for about a week during a trip to the United States.

events.title: Writer's Visit to Maxwell in US
events.description: The letter writer and their son stayed with Ghislaine Maxwell for about a week during a trip to the United States.

events.title: Maxwell's Criminal Charges
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is facing extremely serious criminal charges, which she has repeatedly denied.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The letter is a character reference and bail support statement for Ghislaine Maxwell, written by a long-time friend.
The writer asserts Maxwell's innocence, stating she has repeatedly denied knowledge of or involvement in the criminal conduct alleged.
The writer claims to have never witnessed any inappropriate behavior from Maxwell, even in settings with young children, and would trust her with their care.
The writer's son, who has traveled and stayed with Maxwell, also supports her and stands behind her.
The document is addressed to Judge Alison J. Nathan of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York in December 2020.
